title: Brief mention of the Maldives by Ptolemy
description: Claudius Ptolemy, a Greco-Roman historian and astronomer refers to Maldives in his book 'Geography of Claudius Ptolemy' which was originally titled 'Geographia' written in second century.

title: Earliest recorded occupation in the Maldives
description: Radiocarbon dates from Nilandhoo Foamathi, Faafu Atoll represent the earliest recorded occupation in the Maldives.

title: Probable initial construction of the Buddhist monastery at Kuruhinna Tharaagadu
description: The Buddhist monastery at Kuruhinna Tharaagadu on Kaashidhoo Island, Kaafu Atoll was probably initially constructed during this period.

title: First recorded visit of Maldivians to Rome in 362 AD
description: The Roman historian Amianus Marcelinus (circa 320-390 AD) recorded the first visit of a delegation of Maldivians, called Divis, to Rome in 362 AD. The delegation brought gifts to Emperor Julian, indicating a level of trade and communication between the Maldives and the Roman Empire during this period.

title: Second phase of building of Kuruhinna Tharaagadu Buddhist monastery
description: The second phase of building of the Kuruhinna Tharaagadu Buddhist monastery on Kaashidhoo Island, Kaafu Atoll took place during this period.

title: Earliest Arab reference to trade with Dībājāt
description: The earliest Arab reference to trade with Dībājāt (taken to refer collectively to the Maldive and Laccadive islands) was made by Sulāyman al-Tājir during this year.

title: Merchants of Siraf and Oman trading with the islands
description: Al Masʿūdī mentions merchants of Siraf and Oman trading with the Maldives during this time period.

title: Reign of Srī Bawanāditta, last Buddhist King of the Maldives
description: Srī Bawanāditta was the last Buddhist king of the Maldives and his reign took place during this period.

title: Conversion of Srī Bawanāditta to Islam and commissioning of the first Friday Mosque
description: Srī Bawanāditta converted to Islam, taking the new name and title of Sulṭān Muḥammad al-ʿAdil during this year. The country's first Friday Mosque was commissioned by the sultan in Malé.

title: Reign of Sulṭān (Mute Kalaminja)
Reign of Sulṭān ʿAlī Kalaminja I
Reign of Sulṭān Dinei Kalaminja
Isdhoo Loamaafaanu (copperplates)
description: Details official grants by Sulṭān Dinei Kalaminja Shri Gadanaadeetiya Mahaaradun for the upkeep of mosque he commissioned on Isdhoo. It also records the destruction of Buddhist monuments and monasteries and the confiscation of temple properties to be re-purposed to support the newly constructed mosque on the island

title: Dhanibidhoo Loamaafaanu (copperplates)
description: Details official grants by the king for the upkeep of mosque he commissioned on Dhanbidhoo. It records the suppression of the Buddhism on this island in Hadhummathee Atoll and the establishment of new provisions for endowing Islamic religious institutions in their place

title: Reign of Sulṭān Dihei Kalaminja
Reign of Sulṭān Waṭi Kalaminja
Reign of Sulṭān (unnamed) Kalaminja
Reign of Sulṭān Hudei Kalaminja
Reign of Sulṭān Ayma Kalaminja
Reign of Sulṭān Hali Kalaminja II
Reign of Sulṭān Kalaminja
Reign of Sulṭān Udu Kalaminja
Reign of Sulṭān ʿAlī Kalaminja III
Reign of Sulṭān Yūsuf Kalaminja I
Reign of Sulṭān (unnamed) Kalaminja
Reign of Sulṭān Dāwūd
Reign of Sulṭān ‘Umar Wira
Reign of Sulṭān (Aḥmad) Shihab al-Dīn
Two visits to the Maldives by the Moroccan Muḥammad ibn ‘Abdullah ibn Baṭṭūṭa
description: Recounts the story of the conversion of the islanders to Islam, which he attributes to ‘Abū’l-Barakāt al-Barbarī. Also notes that the islands were exporting dried fish, coir and cowries to Arabia a century before.

title: Reign of Sulṭāna Rehendi (Khadījah) Kabadi Kilege
Malé Bodu-galu Loamaafaanu inscription
Reign of Sulṭān Muḥammad al-Jamīl (Jamal al-Dīn)
description: Muhammad al-Jamil was the husband of Sulṭāna Khadijah and assumed the reign forcibly. He reigned for one year before being murdered by the Sulṭāna.

title: Second Reign of Sulṭāna Rehendi (Khadījah) Kabadi Kilege
Reign of Sulṭān ‘Abdullah I
description: ‘Abdullah I took the throne by force from his wife Sulṭāna Rehendi.

title: Third Reign of Sulṭāna Rehendi (Khadijah) Kabadi Kilege
description: Sulṭāna Rehendi seized the throne by killing her husband Sulṭān ‘Abdullah I.

title: Reign of Sulṭāna Radafati Kadabe Kilege, deposed by Muḥammad Rasge
description: Sulṭāna Radafati Kadabe Kilege was the half-sister of Sulṭāna Khadījah. She was deposed after four months by Muḥammad Rasge of Makuratu.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Muḥammad Rasge
Reign of Sulṭāna Rehendi Dainu Kambadi Kilege, deposed by her husband ‘Abdullah
description: Sulṭāna Rehendi Dainu Kambadi Kilege was deposed after 4 years by her husband ‘Abdullah.

title: Reign of Sulṭān ‘Abdullah II, lasting only one month 15 days
Reign of Sulṭān ‘Uthman of Fehendu, deposed by Ḥasan I
description: Sulṭān ‘Uthman, known thereafter as ‘Uthman of Fehendu, also reigned for little over a month before being deposed by Ḥasan I.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Hilali Ḥasan I
description: Sulṭān Hilali Ḥasan I reigned for 10 years.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Ibrahīm I, deposed by his uncle
description: Sulṭān Ibrahīm I was deposed by his uncle after four months of reign.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Ḥusain I, brother of Hilali Ḥasan I
description: Sulṭān Ḥusain I, brother of Hilali Ḥasan I, reigned for 10 years.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Naṣr al-Dīn
description: Sulṭān Naṣr al-Dīn is credited with commissioning the construction of the Alif and Ba mosques in Malé, as well as a mosque in Machchangoli Avaru.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Ḥasan II
description: Sulṭān Ḥasan II dies nine months into his reign from drowning in Dammat Veyo within the Palace enclosure at Malé.

title: Reign of Sulṭān ‘Īsa, younger half-brother of Sulṭān Ḥasan II
description: Sulṭān ‘Īsa had a short reign of only three months.

title: Second Reign of Sulṭān Ibrahīm I
description: Sulṭān Ibrahīm I's second reign lasted for eight years.

title: Reign of Sulṭān ‘Uthmān II
description: Sulṭān ‘Uthmān II had a short reign of only three months.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Danna Muḥammad, who commissioned the construction of the Henveru Bandara mosque
description: Sulṭān Danna Muḥammad commissioned the construction of the Henveru Bandara mosque.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Yūsuf II
description: Sulṭān Yūsuf II's reign lasted for 22 years.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Abū Bakr
description: Sulṭān Abū Bakr ruled for 7 months before handing over to his son.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Ḥaji Ḥasan III
description: Sulṭān Ḥaji Ḥasan III, who was earlier a qāḍi under Sulṭān Danna Muhammed, ruled for 25 years before departing for the Ḥajj.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Sayyid Muḥammad
description: Sulṭān Sayyid Muḥammad, who had migrated to the Maldives from Arabia, seized power in Ḥasan’s absence and reigned for one year.

title: Second Reign of Sulṭān Ḥasan III
description: Sulṭān Ḥasan III returned from the Ḥajj with over 70 slaves, one of which kills a Maldivian. Ḥasan, on the pretext of a juridical and theological dispute, orders the public burning at the stake of a Persian Qāḍi named Ḥasan Shirazī who he disagrees with over the punishment of the slave. Ḥasan III dies shortly afterwards.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Muḥammad, son of Sulṭān Ḥaji Ḥasan III
description: Sulṭān Muḥammad, son of Sulṭān Ḥaji Ḥasan III, reigns for 13 years

title: Reign of Sulṭān Ḥasan IV
description: Sulṭān Ḥasan IV is deposed after one month by ‘Umar II

title: Reign of Sulṭān ‘Umar II of Goidhoo Atoll
description: Sulṭān ‘Umar II of Goidhoo Atoll relocates the capital of the Sulṭānate for a period

title: Reign of Sulṭān Ḥasan V
Second Reign of Sulṭān Ḥasan IV
Reign of Shaikh Ḥasan VI
Reign of Sulṭān Ibrahīm II
description: Sulṭān Ibrahīm II's reign lasts only 8 months

title: Reign of Sulṭān Kalu Muḥammad Hilali, son of Sulṭān ‘Umar
description: Sulṭān Kalu Muḥammad Hilali is deposed by his brother Yūsuf III after nine months

title: Reign of Sulṭān Yūsuf III/Sulṭān ‘Umar and Reign of Sulṭān ʿAlī IV
description: Sulṭān Yūsuf III ruled for two and a half months under the new name of Sulṭān ‘Umar before his death. He was succeeded by Sulṭān ʿAlī IV, who reigned for two years and four months before being deposed by Kalu Muḥammad Hilali.

title: Second Reign of Sulṭān Kalu Muḥammad Hilali
description: Sulṭān Kalu Muḥammad Hilali began his second reign in 1495, which lasted until 1508. During this time, his capitulation before the ʿAlī Raja of Cannanore of the Mappilla Arakkal clan opened the way for Cannanore to take on a dominant role in Maldivian politics.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Ḥasan VII
description: Sulṭān Ḥasan VII, the nephew of Sulṭān Kalu Muḥammad Hilali, usurped the throne from Hilali and ruled from 1508 to 1510.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Sharīf Aḥmad
description: Sulṭān Sharīf Aḥmad from Makka ruled the Maldives from 1510 to 1512.

title: Reign of Sulṭān ʿAlī V
description: Sulṭān ʿAlī V ruled the Maldives for nine months before being deposed by Kalu Muḥammad.

title: Third Reign of Kalu Muḥammad
description: Kalu Muḥammad ruled the Maldives for the third time, reigning for 16 years.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Ḥasan Shirazī VIII
description: Ḥasan Shirazī VIII was the son of Kalu Muḥammad by a Persian concubine. He ruled the Maldives for 19 years.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Muḥammad
description: Sulṭān Muḥammad was killed two years into his reign by his brother who then seized the throne.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Ḥasan IX
description: Ḥasan IX renounced Islam two and a half years into his reign and left the Maldives for India, where he married a Christian woman in Goa. His apostasy and alliance with the Portuguese is used by the Portuguese to launch a series of expeditions to assert control over the Maldives.

title: Portuguese expedition to Malé ends in failure
description: In 1552, Sultan Hasan IX of the Maldives sent a Portuguese vessel to Malé with instructions to bring the ministers and chiefs to Cochin. However, the ship was seized and all aboard were killed. A second armed expedition from Cochin also suffered the same fate.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Abu Bakr II
description: Sulṭān Abu Bakr II reigned over the Maldives from 1552 to 1556, after succeeding his father Sulṭān Ḥasan IX. He was murdered after only four years in power.

title: Reign of Sulṭān ʿAlī VI
description: Sulṭān ʿAlī VI took the throne in 1558 and reigned for two and a half years. He was killed while defending Malé against the Portuguese.

title: Reign of Captain Adiri Adiri
description: Captain Adiri Adiri declared himself as the Sultan and Christians were sent to each Atoll to act as headmen.

title: Expulsion of the Portuguese and the death of Andiri Andiri
description: Ghazi Muḥammad Bodu Takurufānu sheltering on Kolufuri, forms an expeditionary force that rids the Islands of the Portuguese and kills Andiri Andiri.

title: Reign of Muḥammad Bodu Takurufānu as Sulṭān
description: Under his reign, the 'Askarun were consolidated into one military body.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Ibrahīm III
description: Sulṭān Ibrahīm III ruled the Maldives from 1585 to 1608. He was killed by Malabaris during a battle while attempting to escape by Royal Barque and was buried on Hanna Midu (Himandhoo) Island, Ari Atoll.

title: François Pyrard de Laval is shipwrecked on South Maalhosmadulu Atoll
description: In 1602, François Pyrard de Laval, a French navigator, was shipwrecked on South Maalhosmadulu Atoll in the Maldives. He spent five years there, and an account of his time was published in 1611.

title: Dutch company explores possibilities for trade in the Maldives
description: In 1602, factors of a Dutch company at Middelburg spent five days in the Maldives to explore possibilities for trade there.

title: Sacking of Malé by Malabaris
description: In 1609, Malabaris sacked Malé and returned to Cannanore with Muḥammad Kalu Tuddala (later Sulṭān Muhammed ‘Imad al-Dīn I), who remained a prisoner for several years.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Husain II on Guraidú (Guraidhoo), South Malé Atoll
Reign of Sulṭān Muḥammad ‘Imad al-Dīn
Successful repulsion of a Portuguese armada attack on Malé
description: Locals successfully repulse an attack on Malé by a Portuguese armada of 15 ships under the command of Domingos Ferreyra Belliyagu. After which Muhammed ‘Imad al-Dīn I purchases 12 cannons and commissions the building of a fort and other defensive works including a breakwater to shelter Maldivian craft.

title: Dutch dispatch a vessel to ascertain trade prospects
description: The Dutch despatch a vessel to ascertain the nature and prospects of trade in the Maldives.

title: First annual embassy from the Sulṭān of the Maldives to the Governor of Ceylon
description: The Sulṭān of the Maldives sends the first annual embassy to the Governor of Ceylon, a tradition that would continue into the first half of the twentieth century.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Iskandar Ibrahīm I
description: Sulṭān Iskandar Ibrahīm I rules Maldives from 1648 to 1687, during which customs duties and royal monopolies were revoked and overseas trade flourished. This economic prosperity supported the building of mosques and new waqf endowments.

title: Compilation of the Maldives court chronicle Tārīkh
description: Ḥasan Taj al-Dīn starts compiling the Arabic-language Maldives court chronicle Tārīkh at the request of the Sulṭān. After the death of Ḥasan Taj al-Dīn, the work is continued by his nephew Muḥammad Muhibb al-Dīn and grandson Ibrahīm Siraj al-Dīn.

title: Repulse of attacks by Portuguese and the Ali Raja of Cannanore
description: Attacks by Portuguese and the Ali Raja of Cannanore on the Maldives are repulsed, bringing to an end the annual payments to Ali Raja and the Portuguese.

title: Endowment of a Mosque on Gan Island
description: A wooden waqf inscription (filā fatkoḷu) recording the endowment of a mosque on Gan island.

title: Construction of the Hukuru Miskiiy
description: Sulṭān Iskandar Ibrahīm lays the foundation stone of the Hukuru Miskiiy (Friday Mosque) in Malé. Work completed by 1657.

title: Sulṭān Iskandar Ibrahīm Undertakes the Ḥajj
description: Sulṭān Iskandar Ibrahīm undertakes the Ḥajj in 1666.

title: Sulṭān Iskandar Ibrahīm Returns to Makkah
description: Sulṭān Iskandar Ibrahīm returns to Makkah for a second time in 1683.

title: Arrival of Sayyid Muḥammad Shams al-Dīn and Religious Reforms in Malé
description: In 1686, Islamic scholar Sayyid Muḥammad Shams al-Dīn arrived in Malé and received the patronage of Sulṭān Iskandar Ibrahīm. Under his influence, several religiously-inspired reforms were introduced, including the order for men to grow beards and the prohibition of wearing the customary silver belt. Women were also required to wear veils in public or remain at home.

title: Sayyid Muḥammad Shams-al-Dīn leaves for India
description: Sayyid Muḥammad Shams-al-Dīn arrived in Malé in 1686 and introduced several religiously-inspired reforms, including the requirement for men to grow beards and for women to wear veils in public or remain at home. However, he later failed in his attempt to challenge Sulṭān Iskandar Ibrahīm and left for India in 1686 or 1687.

title: Assassination of Sulṭān Iskandar Ibrahīm and Reign of Sulṭān Kuda Muḥammad
description: In 1687, Sulṭān Iskandar Ibrahīm was killed by poison administered by his senior concubine and mother of his son, Mariyam. Following his death, his six-year old son Sulṭān Kuda Muḥammad became the ruler, with his mother seizing rule on behalf of him and appointing her brothers to the role of wazīrs. This period lasted from 1687-1691. In 1691, Tiladummati Atoll was attacked by Indian ‘pirate’ vessels which were successfully repulsed by the Maldivian fleet, but during celebrations sparks falling into a powder magazine of the boat carrying the Sulṭān and his mother causing an explosion in which both were killed.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Kuda Muḥammad
description: Sulṭān Kuda Muḥammad was the son of Sulṭān Iskandar Ibrahīm and his concubine Mariyam Kabafanu. His mother seized rule on behalf of him and appointed her brothers to the role of wazīrs. This period lasted from 1687-1691. In 1691, Tiladummati Atoll was attacked by Indian ‘pirate’ vessels which were successfully repulsed by the Maldivian fleet, but during celebrations sparks falling into a powder magazine of the boat carrying the Sulṭān and his mother causing an explosion in which both were killed.

title: Attack on Tiladummati Atoll
description: In 1691, Tiladummati Atoll was attacked by Indian ‘pirate’ vessels which were successfully repulsed by the Maldivian fleet, but during celebrations sparks falling into a powder magazine of the boat carrying the Sulṭān and his mother causing an explosion in which both were killed.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Muḥammad Muḥyi al-Dīn al-Adil
description: Sulṭān Muḥammad Muḥyi al-Dīn al-Adil, the half-brother of Sulṭān Iskandar Ibrahīm, granted the right to all Maldivians to go on the Ḥajj directly from Malé. Until that time, travel was in Malabar vessels from India. This has been characterized as a period in which Maldivian society became more egalitarian, and foreigners were also treated on terms of equality. Shortly before his death, the sultan invited the Arab scholar Muḥammad Shams al-Dīn to return to the Maldives.

title: Death of Sulṭān Muḥammad Muḥyi al-Dīn al-ʿAdil
description: Sulṭān Muḥammad Muḥyi al-Dīn al-ʿAdil reigned for almost two years until his death and was buried in the cemetery at Huskuru Miskiiy.

title: Reign of Sayyid Muḥammad Shams al-Dīn I
description: Sayyid Muḥammad Shams al-Dīn I reigned for less than 5 months before dying of a fever. He was buried within the Medu Ziyarat alongside Shaykh Yūsuf Shams al-Dīn al-Tabrīzi.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Muḥammad
description: Sulṭān Muḥammad married Mariyam, the widow of Sulṭān Muḥyi al-Dīn.

title: Reign of Sulṭān ʿAlī VII
description: Sulṭān ʿAlī VII dies after an unpopular reign of nine months.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Ḥasan X
description: Sulṭān Ḥasan X, son of ʿAlī VII aged 13 or 14, came to the throne in 1701. However, he was ousted from the throne by his cousin Ibrahīm Shah Bandar and others who conspired against him. Ibrahīm Shah Bandar was appointed to administer the Government as his guardian.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Ibrahīm Muẓhir al-Dīn
description: Sulṭān Ibrahīm Muẓhir al-Dīn ruled from 1701 to 1704. During his reign, he commissioned the construction of two bathing tanks: the Ma Veyo at Doru Miskiiy, Machchangoli Avaru and another within the Hukuru Miskiiy precincts at Malé. It was erroneously reported that he died during a shipwreck off the coast of India in 1705 while returning from the Ḥajj, alongside the nephew he dethroned.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Muzaffar Muḥammad ‘Imad al- Dīn II
description: Sulṭān Muzaffar Muḥammad ‘Imad al- Dīn II ascended the throne after false reports of the death of Sulṭān Ibrahīm Muẓhir al-Dīn at sea. During his eighteen-year reign, the former Sulṭān Ibrahīm returned to Malé but was banished to Fuvamulah, whence he escaped to Ceylon and later to Senna-Paddanam (Madras) where the Commandant of an English fort showed him ‘much consideration’. Three attempts to regain the throne were unsuccessful, and the date and place of his death are unknown.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Iskandar II
description: Sulṭān Iskandar II reigned from 1721 to 1750. During his reign, the first circular coins were issued in the Maldives.

title: Fire and earthquake in Malé
description: In 1730, a fire destroyed much of Henveru Ward in Malé. The islands also reportedly experienced an earthquake.

title: Cyclone devastates northern Atolls
description: In 1733, a cyclone reached the Maldives, devastating and submerging a number of islands in the northern Atolls with loss of life and property.

title: Famine in Malé
Tornado and fire strike Malé
description: In 1742, a tornado struck Malé, and two weeks later, a fire in Henvera Avaru destroyed many buildings, including the Attarafanin Miskiiy.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Mukarram Muḥammad ’Imad al- Dīn III
Expedition from Malabar captures Malé
description: In 1753, an expedition from Malabar under the behest of ʿAlī Raja of Cannanore captured Malé and destroyed the palace. Four months later, Malé was retaken by Maldivians led by Ḥasan Manikufanu. A further contingent sent by ʿAlī Raja plundered Tiladummati and Fadifulu Atolls. A French fleet under the command of Le Termellier arrived to support the Maldivian forces.

title: French contingent departs from Malé
description: In 1754, the French contingent who were quartered in Malé departed after an altercation with the local authorities.

title: Sulṭān Mukarram Muḥammad ‘Imad al-Dīn III and his nephew sent to a fort in Cannanore
description: In 1757, Sulṭān Mukarram Muḥammad ‘Imad al-Dīn III and his nephew were sent to a fort in Cannanore where they were guarded by Turkish and Malabari soldiers. The Sulṭān was later transferred to Minicoy where he died in 1757.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Ghazi Ḥasan ‘Izz al-Dīnal-Dīn
description: Sulṭān Ghazi Ḥasan ‘Izz al-Dīn reigned from 1759 to 1767.

title: Earthquake followed by a fire destroys Danna Muḥammad Miskiiy
description: In 1759, an earthquake followed by a fire destroyed Danna Muḥammad Miskiiy.

title: Malabar Expedition briefly occupies Funadhoo and Hulhule islands
description: In 1761, the Malabar Expedition briefly occupied Funadhoo and Hulhule islands.

title: Sulṭān Ghazi Ḥasan ‘Izz al-Dīn dies, nominating Muḥammad as his successor
description: In 1767, Sulṭān Ghazi Ḥasan ‘Izz al-Dīn died and nominated Muḥammad, son of Iskandar II, as his successor.

title: Reign of Muḥammad Giyath al-Dīn
description: Muḥammad Giyath al-Dīn was unanimously elected by the people and ruled from 1766 to 1774.

title: Expedition by ʿAlī Raja of Cannanore Repulsed
description: An expedition of nine ships sent by ʿAlī Raja of Cannanore bombards Malé but is repulsed in 1771.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Muḥammad Shams al-Dīn II
description: Sulṭān Muḥammad Shams al-Dīn II reigned from 1773 to 1774. Kaluvakara Miskiiy was commissioned by him and completed during the reign of Sulṭān Ḥasan Nur al-Dīn. He later transfers the throne to Muḥammad, eldest son of Sulṭān Ḥasan ‘Izz al-Dīn (Muḥammad Farina Kilegafanu).

title: Reign of Sulṭān Muḥammad Mu’izzal-Dīn
description: Sulṭān Muḥammad Mu’izzal-Dīn ruled the Maldives from 1774 to 1779. He succeeded Sulṭān Muḥammad Shams al-Dīn II and was followed by Sulṭān Muḥammad Mueenuddine I. Not much is known about his reign.

title: Seizure and Secret Drowning of Sultan Giyath al-Din
description: Sultan Giyath al-Din, who had returned from Makkah and was resigned to the loss of his throne, was seized and secretly drowned in 1774.

title: Deaths of Sulṭān Muḥammad Shams al-Dīn II and Sulṭān Mu’izz al-Dīn
Reign of Sulṭān Ḥasan Nur al-Dīn
description: Sulṭān Ḥasan Nur al-Dīn was the younger brother of Sulṭān Muḥammad Mu’izz-al-Dīn.

title: Death of Qāḍi Muḥammad Muḥibb al-Dīn
description: Qāḍi Muḥammad Muḥibb al-Dīn was a contributor to the Tarikh, a historical chronicle of the Maldives. His contributions are believed to have been related to the period of Islamic conversion in the Maldives.

title: First Ḥajj pilgrimage of Ḥasan Nur al-Dīn
description: Ḥasan Nur al-Dīn made his first Ḥajj pilgrimage in 1789 and returned in the same year. Aḥmad Dorimena Takurufanu was nominated regent.

title: British expel the Dutch from Ceylon and incorporate Maldives as a protectorate
description: In 1796, the British expelled the Dutch from Ceylon (Sri Lanka) after taking control of the Dutch possessions in India. They also incorporated the Maldives as a protectorate in the same year, bringing the archipelago under British influence. This move allowed the British to control important sea routes and secure their interests in the Indian Ocean region.

title: Wreck of Indian Vessel and Maldivian Appropriation of Gold, Coins and Jewellery
description: In 1797, an Indian vessel captured by the French was wrecked on an island in Huvadhu Atoll. The Maldivians appropriated gold, coins, and jewellery from the wreckage, and some of it was shipped in the Sultan's vessel bound for Makkah.

title: Second Ḥajj pilgrimage of Sulṭān Nur al-Dīn
description: In 1798, Sulṭān Nur al-Dīn undertook his second Ḥajj pilgrimage. His son, Muḥammad Mu’inal-Dīn, was made Prince Regent during his absence. Despite warnings by Sherif Galib of Makka not to risk the seizure of so much treasure, the Sulṭān went ahead with his plans. His vessels were plundered of treasure and guns, and upon finally reaching Jeddah, he died of smallpox. A further 230 of the pilgrims died while making a slow return to the Maldives. Several islands were abandoned during this reign, and Jum’a Miskiiy was built on Giravaru Island, North Malé Atoll.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Muḥammad Mu’in-al-Dīn I
description: Sulṭān Muḥammad Mu’in-al-Dīn I ruled the Maldives from 1799 to 1835. During his reign, the ‘Idu Miskiiy (Khutba Mosque) in Malé was rebuilt, and a new mosque was built on Edafuri Island in the Malosmadulu Atoll.

title: Earthquake felt across Tiladummati Atoll to Fivaku in Miladummadulu Atoll
description: In 1815, an earthquake was felt across Tiladummati Atoll to Fivaku in Miladummadulu Atoll. The earthquake was followed by several aftershocks.

title: Great famine on the Maldives islands
description: Between 1819 and 1826, a great famine occurred on the Maldives islands, resulting in widespread hunger and suffering among the population. The famine was caused by a combination of factors, including poor harvests, drought, and a decline in fishing yields. It is estimated that thousands of people died during this period due to starvation and related diseases.

title: Devastating Tornado Hits the Maldives
description: In 1822, a destructive tornado struck the Maldives, causing significant damage and loss of life. According to Yajima, the storm was recorded in the Tārīkh chronicle as occurring in 1237 AH, which is equivalent to 1822 CE. The tornado resulted in the drowning of a number of people and the devastation of several islands.

title: Death of Sultan Muhammad Mu'in al-Din I
Reign of Sulṭān Muḥammad ‘Imad al-Dīn IV
description: Sulṭān Muḥammad ‘Imad al-Dīn IV was the son of Sulṭān Muḥammad Mu’in-al-Dīn I and ruled as the Sultan of the Rasulid dynasty in Yemen from 1835 to 1882.

title: Henry Charles Purvis (H.C.P.) Bell's first visit to Maldives
description: In 1879, Henry Charles Purvis (H.C.P.) Bell, former Archaeological Commissioner and Head of the Archaeological Survey of Ceylon, made his first visit to the Maldives. Following his retirement, Bell conducted research on the history, archaeology, and epigraphy of the Maldives, as well as studied the linguistics of the Maldivian language.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Ibrahīm Nur al-Dīn
Abdication of Sulṭān Ibrahīm Nur al-Dīn
Reign of Sulṭān Muḥammad Mu’in al-Dīn II
State agreement with the British Crown signed
description: In 1887, Sulṭān Muḥammad Mu’inal-Dīn II signed a state agreement with the British Crown which recognized the suzerainty of the British Sovereign over the Maldive Islands. As part of the agreement, the Sultan disclaimed all rights to enter into negotiations or treaties with other countries except through the ruler of Ceylon. In return, Britain agreed to protect the Maldives against foreign enemies and established it as a self-governing British protectorate.

title: Second Reign of Sulṭān Ibrahīm Nural-Dīn
description: Uncle of Sultan Muhammadh Mueenuddeen II

title: Reign of Sulṭān ‘Imad al-Dīn V
description: His cousin Hassan Nooreddine Maandhoogey Manippulu acted as his regent due to his age. The regent abdicated in his name in favour of his older half brother.

title: Sulṭān Muḥammad Shams-al-Dīn II becomes ruler for three months
description: Sulṭān Muḥammad Shams-al-Dīn II, who was only 12 years old at the time, briefly held the position of ruler for three months in 1893.

title: Reign of Sulṭān Haji Muhammad Imaaduddeen VI Iskandar
description: Former regent for Sultans Muhammad Imaaduddeen V and Muhammad Shamsuddeen III. Deposed while in the Ottoman Empire.

title: Second Reign of Sultan Muhammad Shamsuddeen Iskander III
description: Introduced the first Constitution which ended when he was deposed and exiled.

title: Reign of Sultan Hassan Nooraddeen Iskandar II
description: The coronation of Sultan Hassan Nooraddeen Iskandar II was on August 20, 1938, though he assumed the throne 3 years earlier on February 2, 1935. During his reign, he faced challenges such as the outbreak of World War II, which affected the economy and trade of the Maldives. Despite these challenges, he managed to maintain stability in the country. In 1943, he was forced to abdicate the throne due to political reasons.

title: Sultan Abdul Majeed Didi Elected
description: Abdul Majeed Didi was elected Sultan but continued to live in Ceylon. Maldives ruled by Council of Regency headed for a time by former Sultan Hassan Nooraddeen II.

title: Referendum on a New Constitution to form a Republic
description: On April 18, 1953, a referendum was held in Maldives on a new constitution to form a republic, following the death of Sultan Abdul Majeed Didi and the refusal of Mohamed Amin Didi to accept the crown and throne.

title: Mohamed Amin Didi becomes the first President of Republic of Maldives
description: On January 1, 1953, the new constitution came into force , and Mohamed Amin Didi became the country's first President after winning almost 96% of the vote in an election

title: Reign of King Muhammad Fareed Didi
description: The last Sultan of Maldives, Muhammad Fareed Didi was the grandson of Sultan Muhammad Mueenuddeen II and eldest son of Sultan Abdul Majeed Didi. He took the title of King Muhammad Fareed Didi in 1965 when the British protectorate of the Maldives ended. His reign ended in 1968 when a national referendum decided to replace the sultanate with a republic.
